For a more sophisticated equivalent of a gerrymander, check out what ran for decades in Queensland, Australia, where a number of premiers, most notoriously Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen, ran the state with as little as 22% of the primary vote.  This was done through a zonal system, where those lived in rural electorates (equivalent of American districts) had more than twice as much voting power as those in metropolitan electorates.  Look up "Bjelkemander" on Wikipedia, or check out the YouTube video of the 1989 election (ABC 1989 Queensland Election) and see Quentin Dempster's excellent explanation of the system (at about the five minute mark).Today, though, we are seeing a new problem in Queensland.  With a population that is increasingly based in a couple of urban centres, one-vote-one-value is now forcing fewer and fewer rural seats that are geographically huge and with much more diverse needs, resulting in less representation for them.  I personally would like to see them increase the number of parliamentarians (for the first time since 1986) to allow for smaller electorates while maintaining equal representation.  Sadly, the current government won't allow this.
